params.name: user_id
params.description: The ID of the user to remove as a moderator from the broadcaster’s chat room.

codes.400:
- The ID in broadcaster_id was not found.
- The ID in user_id was not found.
- The user in user_id is not a moderator in the broadcaster's chat room.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:moderators scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.429: - The broadcaster has exceeded the number of requests allowed within a 10-second window. See this endpoint's rate limits.

Remove Channel Moderator.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:moderators* scope.

Get VIPs.short: Gets a list of the broadcaster’s VIPs.
Get VIPs.long: Gets a list of the broadcaster’s VIPs.

params.name: user_id
params.description: Filters the list for specific VIPs. To specify more than one user, include the user_id parameter for each user to get. For example, `&user_id=1234&user_id=5678`. The maximum number of IDs that you may specify is 100. Ignores the ID of those users in the list that aren’t VIPs.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose list of VIPs you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of VIPs. The list is empty if the broadcaster doesn’t have VIP users.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: An ID that uniquely identifies the VIP user.

reqBody.name: user_name
reqBody.description: The user’s display name.

reqBody.name: user_login
reqBody.description: The user’s login name.

reqBody.name: pagination
reqBody.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s list of VIPs.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the user_id query parameter is not valid.
- The number of user_id query parameters exceeds the maximum allowed.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:read:vips or channel:manage:vips scope.
- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the OAuth token.

Get VIPs.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:read:vips* scope. If your app also adds and removes VIP status, you can use the *channel:manage:vips* scope instead.

Add Channel VIP.short: Adds the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
Add Channel VIP.long:
Adds the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may add a maximum of 10 VIPs within a 10-second window.

params.name: user_id
params.description: The ID of the user to give VIP status to.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s adding the user as a VIP. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

Add Channel VIP.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:vips* scope.

Remove Channel VIP.short: Removes the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
Remove Channel VIP.long:
Removes the specified user as a VIP in the broadcaster’s channel.
If the broadcaster is removing the user’s VIP status, the ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token; otherwise, if the user is removing their VIP status themselves, the ID in the user_id query parameter must match the user ID in the access token.
*Rate Limits*: The broadcaster may remove a maximum of 10 VIPs within a 10-second window.

params.name: user_id
params.description: The ID of the user to remove VIP status from.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster who owns the channel where the user has VIP status.

Remove Channel VIP.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:vips* scope.

Update Shield Mode Status.short: Activates or deactivates the broadcaster’s Shield Mode.
Update Shield Mode Status.long:
Activates or deactivates the broadcaster’s Shield Mode.
Twitch’s Shield Mode feature is like a panic button that broadcasters can push to protect themselves from chat abuse coming from one or more accounts. When activated, Shield Mode applies the overrides that the broadcaster configured in the Twitch UX. If the broadcaster hasn’t configured Shield Mode, it applies default overrides.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose Shield Mode you want to activate or deactivate.

params.name: moderator_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that is one of the broadcaster’s moderators. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

reqBody.name: is_active
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether to activate Shield Mode. Set to *true* to activate Shield Mode; otherwise, *false* to deactivate Shield Mode.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains a single object with the broadcaster’s updated Shield Mode status.

reqBody.name: is_active
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether Shield Mode is active. Is *true* if Shield Mode is active; otherwise, *false*.

reqBody.name: moderator_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the moderator that last activated Shield Mode.

reqBody.name: moderator_login
reqBody.description: The moderator’s login name.

reqBody.name: moderator_name
reqBody.description: The moderator’s display name.

reqBody.name: last_activated_at
reqBody.description: The UTC timestamp (in RFC3339 format) of when Shield Mode was last activated.

codes.200: Successfully updated the broadcaster’s Shield Mode status.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
- The `is_active` field is required.
- The value in the `is_active` field is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:shield_mode scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Update Shield Mode Status.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *moderator:manage:shield_mode* scope.

Get Shield Mode Status.short: Gets the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
Get Shield Mode Status.long:
Gets the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
To receive notification when the broadcaster activates and deactivates Shield Mode, subscribe to the [channel.shield_mode.begin](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelshield_modebegin) and [channel.shield_mode.end](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelshield_modeend) subscription types.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose Shield Mode activation status you want to get.

params.name: moderator_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster or a user that is one of the broadcaster’s moderators. This ID must match the user ID in the access token.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains a single object with the broadcaster’s Shield Mode status.

reqBody.name: is_active
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether Shield Mode is active. Is *true* if the broadcaster activated Shield Mode; otherwise, *false*.

reqBody.name: moderator_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the moderator that last activated Shield Mode. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

reqBody.name: moderator_login
reqBody.description: The moderator’s login name. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

reqBody.name: moderator_name
reqBody.description: The moderator’s display name. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

reqBody.name: last_activated_at
reqBody.description: The UTC timestamp (in RFC3339 format) of when Shield Mode was last activated. Is an empty string if Shield Mode hasn’t been previously activated.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s Shield Mode activation status.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:read:shield_mode or moderator:manage:shield_mode scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Get Shield Mode Status.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *moderator:read:shield_mode* or *moderator:manage:shield_mode* scope.

Warn Chat User.short: Warns a user in the specified broadcaster’s chat room, preventing them from chat interaction until the warning is acknowledged.
Warn Chat User.long: Warns a user in the specified broadcaster’s chat room, preventing them from chat interaction until the warning is acknowledged. New warnings can be issued to a user when they already have a warning in the channel (new warning will replace old warning).

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the channel in which the warning will take effect.

params.name: moderator_id
params.description: The ID of the twitch user who requested the warning.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains information about the warning.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the twitch user to be warned.

reqBody.name: reason
reqBody.description: A custom reason for the warning. *Max 500 chars.*

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains information about the warning.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the channel in which the warning will take effect.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the warned user.

reqBody.name: moderator_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the user who applied the warning.

reqBody.name: reason
reqBody.description: The reason provided for warning.

codes.200: Successfully warn a user.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The moderator_id query parameter is required.
- The user_id query parameter is required.
- The reason query parameter is required.
- The text in the reason field is too long.
- The user specified in the user_id may not be warned.
codes.401:
- The ID in moderator_id must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the moderator:manage:warnings scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: The user in moderator_id is not one of the broadcaster’s moderators.
codes.409: You may not update the user’s warning state while someone else is updating the state. For example, someone else is currently warning the user or the user is acknowledging an existing warning. Please retry your request.
codes.429: The app has exceeded the number of requests it may make per minute for this broadcaster.

Warn Chat User.auth: Requires a user access token that includes the *moderator:manage:warnings* scope. Query parameter `moderator_id` must match the `user_id` in the [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication/#user-access-tokens).

Add Suspicious Status to Chat User.short: NEW Adds a suspicious user status to a chatter on the broadcaster’s channel.
Add Suspicious Status to Chat User.long: NEW Adds a suspicious user status to a chatter on the broadcaster’s channel.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The user ID of the broadcaster, indicating the channel where the status is being applied.

params.name: moderator_id
params.description: The user ID of the moderator who is applying the status.

Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.short: NEW Remove a suspicious user status from a chatter on broadcaster’s channel.
Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.long: NEW Remove a suspicious user status from a chatter on broadcaster’s channel.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The user ID of the broadcaster, indicating the channel where the status is being removed.

params.name: moderator_id
params.description: The user ID of the moderator who is removing the status.

params.name: user_id
params.description: The ID of the user having the suspicious status removed.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: An array with one object containing information about the suspicious user action.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the user having the suspicious status removed.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: The user ID of the broadcaster indicating in which channel the status is being removed.

reqBody.name: moderator_id

reqBody.name: updated_at

reqBody.name: types
reqBody.description: An array of strings representing the type(s) of suspicious user this is. Possible values are: MANUALLY_ADDED, DETECTED_BAN_EVADER, DETECTED_SUS_CHATTER, BANNED_IN_SHARED_CHANNEL

codes.200: Successfully removed a suspicious user status.
codes.400:
- Validation errors: Missing required fields.

codes.401:

- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the OAuth token.
codes.403: - The user in the moderator_id query parameter is not one of the broadcaster's moderators.

Remove Suspicious Status From Chat User.auth: Requires an [app access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#app-access-tokens) or [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *moderator:manage:suspicious_users* scope.

Get Polls.short: Gets a list of polls that the broadcaster created.
Get Polls.long:
Gets a list of polls that the broadcaster created.
Polls are available for 90 days after they’re created.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that created the polls. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

params.name: id
params.description: A list of IDs that identify the polls to return. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each poll you want to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 20 IDs.Specify this parameter only if you want to filter the list that the request returns. The endpoint ignores duplicate IDs and those not owned by this broadcaster.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 20 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list of polls. The polls are returned in descending order of start time unless you specify IDs in the request, in which case they're returned in the same order as you passed them in the request. The list is empty if the broadcaster hasn't created polls.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the poll.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the poll.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_name
reqBody.description: The broadcaster's display name.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_login
reqBody.description: The broadcaster's login name.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The question that viewers are voting on. For example, What game should I play next? The title may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

reqBody.name: choices
reqBody.description: A list of choices that viewers can choose from. The list will contain a minimum of two choices and up to a maximum of five choices.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this choice.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The choice's title. The title may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

reqBody.name: votes
reqBody.description: The total number of votes cast for this choice.

reqBody.name: channel_points_votes
reqBody.description: The number of votes cast using Channel Points.

reqBody.name: bits_votes
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

reqBody.name: bits_voting_enabled
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to *false*.

reqBody.name: bits_per_vote
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

reqBody.name: channel_points_voting_enabled
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

reqBody.name: channel_points_per_vote
reqBody.description: The number of points the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote.

reqBody.name: status
reqBody.description:
The poll's status. Valid values are:- ACTIVE — The poll is running.
- COMPLETED — The poll ended on schedule (see the `duration` field).
- TERMINATED — The poll was terminated before its scheduled end.
- ARCHIVED — The poll has been archived and is no longer visible on the channel.
- MODERATED — The poll was deleted.
- INVALID — Something went wrong while determining the state.

reqBody.name: duration
reqBody.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for.

reqBody.name: started_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll began.

reqBody.name: ended_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this field is set to *null*.

reqBody.name: pagination
reqBody.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request's after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster's polls.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token is missing the channel:read:polls scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header must match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404: - None of the IDs in the id query parameters were found.

Get Polls.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:read:polls* or *channel:manage:polls* scope.

Create Poll.short: Creates a poll that viewers in the broadcaster’s channel can vote on.
Create Poll.long:
Creates a poll that viewers in the broadcaster’s channel can vote on.
The poll begins as soon as it’s created. You may run only one poll at a time.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the poll. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The question that viewers will vote on. For example, What game should I play next? The question may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

reqBody.name: choices
reqBody.description: A list of choices that viewers may choose from. The list must contain a minimum of 2 choices and up to a maximum of 5 choices.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: One of the choices the viewer may select. The choice may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

reqBody.name: duration
reqBody.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for. The minimum is 15 seconds and the maximum is 1800 seconds (30 minutes).

reqBody.name: channel_points_voting_enabled
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. If *true*, the viewer may cast more than one vote but each additional vote costs the number of Channel Points specified in `channel_points_per_vote`. The default is *false* (viewers may cast only one vote). For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

reqBody.name: channel_points_per_vote
reqBody.description: The number of points that the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote. The minimum is 1 and the maximum is 1000000. Set only if `ChannelPointsVotingEnabled` is *true*.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains the single poll that you created.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the poll.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the poll.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_name
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s display name.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_login
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s login name.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The question that viewers are voting on. For example, What game should I play next? The title may contain a maximum of 60 characters.

reqBody.name: choices
reqBody.description: A list of choices that viewers can choose from. The list will contain a minimum of two choices and up to a maximum of five choices.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this choice.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The choice’s title. The title may contain a maximum of 25 characters.

reqBody.name: votes
reqBody.description: The total number of votes cast for this choice.

reqBody.name: channel_points_votes
reqBody.description: The number of votes cast using Channel Points.

reqBody.name: bits_votes
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

reqBody.name: bits_voting_enabled
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to *false*.

reqBody.name: bits_per_vote
reqBody.description: Not used; will be set to 0.

reqBody.name: channel_points_voting_enabled
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether viewers may cast additional votes using Channel Points. For information about Channel Points, see [Channel Points Guide](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-points-guide).

reqBody.name: channel_points_per_vote
reqBody.description: The number of points the viewer must spend to cast one additional vote.

reqBody.name: status
reqBody.description:
The poll’s status. Valid values are:- ACTIVE — The poll is running.
- COMPLETED — The poll ended on schedule (see the `duration` field).
- TERMINATED — The poll was terminated before its scheduled end.
- ARCHIVED — The poll has been archived and is no longer visible on the channel.
- MODERATED — The poll was deleted.
- INVALID — Something went wrong while determining the state.

reqBody.name: duration
reqBody.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the poll will run for.

reqBody.name: started_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll began.

reqBody.name: ended_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the poll ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this field is set to *null*.

codes.200: Successfully created the poll.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `title` field is required.
- The `choices` field is required.
- The `duration` field is required.
- The value in `duration` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The value in `channel_points_per_vote` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The value in `bits_per_vote` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The poll's `title` is too long.
- The choice's `title` is too long.
- The choice's `title` failed AutoMod checks.
- The number of choices in the poll may not be less than 2 or greater that 5.
- The broadcaster already has a poll that's running; you may not create another poll until the current poll completes.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token is missing the channel:manage:polls scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Create Poll.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:polls* scope.

End Poll.long: Ends an active poll. You have the option to end it or end it and archive it.

Get Predictions.short: Gets a list of Channel Points Predictions that the broadcaster created.
Get Predictions.long: Gets a list of Channel Points Predictions that the broadcaster created.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose predictions you want to get. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

params.name: id
params.description: The ID of the prediction to get. To specify more than one ID, include this parameter for each prediction you want to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 25 IDs. The endpoint ignores duplicate IDs and those not owned by the broadcaster.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 25 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s list of Channel Points Predictions. The list is sorted in descending ordered by when the prediction began (the most recent prediction is first). The list is empty if the broadcaster hasn’t created predictions.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this prediction.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the broadcaster that created the prediction.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_name
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s display name.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_login
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s login name.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The question that the prediction asks. For example, Will I finish this entire pizza?

reqBody.name: winning_outcome_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the winning outcome. Is *null* unless `status` is RESOLVED.

reqBody.name: outcomes
reqBody.description: The list of possible outcomes for the prediction.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this outcome.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The outcome’s text.

reqBody.name: users
reqBody.description: The number of unique viewers that chose this outcome.

reqBody.name: channel_points
reqBody.description: The number of Channel Points spent by viewers on this outcome.

reqBody.name: top_predictors
reqBody.description: A list of viewers who were the top predictors; otherwise, *null* if none.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the viewer.

reqBody.name: user_name
reqBody.description: The viewer’s display name.

reqBody.name: user_login
reqBody.description: The viewer’s login name.

reqBody.name: channel_points_used
reqBody.description: The number of Channel Points the viewer spent.

reqBody.name: channel_points_won
reqBody.description: The number of Channel Points distributed to the viewer.

reqBody.name: color
reqBody.description:
The color that visually identifies this outcome in the UX. Possible values are:- BLUE
- PINK
If the number of outcomes is two, the color is BLUE for the first outcome and PINK for the second outcome. If there are more than two outcomes, the color is BLUE for all outcomes.

reqBody.name: prediction_window
reqBody.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for.

reqBody.name: status
reqBody.description:
The prediction’s status. Valid values are:- ACTIVE — The Prediction is running and viewers can make predictions.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster canceled the Prediction and refunded the Channel Points to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster locked the Prediction, which means viewers can no longer make predictions.
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome was determined and the Channel Points were distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.

reqBody.name: created_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction began.

reqBody.name: ended_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction ended. If `status` is ACTIVE, this is set to *null*.

reqBody.name: locked_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time of when the Prediction was locked. If `status` is not LOCKED, this is set to *null*.

reqBody.name: pagination
reqBody.description: Contains the information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Use the cursor to set the request’s after query parameter.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of predictions.
codes.400: - The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:read:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Get Predictions.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:read:predictions* or *channel:manage:predictions* scope.

Create Prediction.long:
Creates a Channel Points Prediction.
With a Channel Points Prediction, the broadcaster poses a question and viewers try to predict the outcome. The prediction runs as soon as it’s created. The broadcaster may run only one prediction at a time.

reqBody.name: title

reqBody.name: prediction_window
reqBody.description: The length of time (in seconds) that the prediction will run for. The minimum is 30 seconds and the maximum is 1800 seconds (30 minutes).

codes.200: Successfully created the Channel Points Prediction.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `title` field is required.
- The `outcomes` field is required.
- The `prediction_window` field is required.
- The value in `prediction_window` is outside the allowed range of values.
- The prediction's `title` is too long.
- The outcome's `title` is too long.
- The outcome's `title` failed AutoMod checks.
- There must be 2 outcomes in the prediction.
- The broadcaster already has a prediction that's running; you may not create another prediction until the current prediction is resolved or canceled.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Create Prediction.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:predictions* scope.

End Prediction.short: Locks, resolves, or cancels a Channel Points Prediction.
End Prediction.long: Locks, resolves, or cancels a Channel Points Prediction.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s running the prediction. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: The ID of the prediction to update.

reqBody.name: status
reqBody.description:
The status to set the prediction to. Possible case-sensitive values are:- RESOLVED — The winning outcome is determined and the Channel Points are distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster is canceling the prediction and sending refunds to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster is locking the prediction, which means viewers may no longer make predictions.
The broadcaster can update an active prediction to LOCKED, RESOLVED, or CANCELED; and update a locked prediction to RESOLVED or CANCELED.The broadcaster has up to 24 hours after the prediction window closes to resolve the prediction. If not, Twitch sets the status to CANCELED and returns the points.

reqBody.name: winning_outcome_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the winning outcome. You must set this parameter if you set `status` to RESOLVED.

The color that visually identifies this outcome in the UX. Possible values are:- BLUE
- PINK
If the number of outcomes is two, the color is BLUE for the first outcome and PINK for the second outcome. If there are more than two outcomes, the color is BLUE for all outcomes.

reqBody.name: prediction_window

reqBody.name: status
reqBody.description:
The prediction’s status. Valid values are:- ACTIVE — The Prediction is running and viewers can make predictions.
- CANCELED — The broadcaster canceled the Prediction and refunded the Channel Points to the participants.
- LOCKED — The broadcaster locked the Prediction, which means viewers can no longer make predictions.
- RESOLVED — The winning outcome was determined and the Channel Points were distributed to the viewers who predicted the correct outcome.

reqBody.name: created_at

reqBody.name: ended_at

codes.200: Successfully ended the prediction.
codes.400:
- The `broadcaster_id` field is required.
- The `id` field is required.
- The `status` field is required.
- The `winning_outcome_id` field is required if `status` is RESOLVED.
- The value in the `status` field is not valid.
- To update the prediction's status to RESOLVED or CANCELED, its current status must be ACTIVE or LOCKED.
- To update the prediction's status to LOCKED, its current status must be ACTIVE.
codes.401:
- The ID in `broadcaster_id` must match the user ID in the OAuth token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:predictions scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404:
- The prediction in the `id` field was not found.
- The outcome in the `winning_outcome_id` field was not found.

End Prediction.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:predictions* scope.

Start a raid.short: Raid another channel by sending the broadcaster’s viewers to the targeted channel.
Start a raid.long:
Raid another channel by sending the broadcaster’s viewers to the targeted channel.
When you call the API from a chat bot or extension, the Twitch UX pops up a window at the top of the chat room that identifies the number of viewers in the raid. The raid occurs when the broadcaster clicks *Raid Now* or after the 90-second countdown expires.
To determine whether the raid successfully occurred, you must subscribe to the [Channel Raid](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelraid) event. For more information, see [Get notified when a raid begins](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/raids#get-notified-when-a-raid-begins).
To cancel a pending raid, use the [Cancel a raid](#cancel-a-raid) endpoint.
*Rate Limit*: The limit is 10 requests within a 10-minute window.

params.name: from_broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s sending the raiding party. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

params.name: to_broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster to raid.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains a single object with information about the pending raid.

reqBody.name: created_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time, in RFC3339 format, of when the raid was requested.

reqBody.name: is_mature
reqBody.description: *IMPORTANT* This field is deprecated and returns only `false`.A Boolean value that indicates whether the channel being raided contains mature content.

codes.200: Successfully requested to start a raid. To determine whether the raid successfully occurred (that is, the broadcaster clicked *Raid Now* or the countdown expired), you must subscribe to the [Channel Raid](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/eventsub/eventsub-subscription-types#channelraid) event.
codes.400:
- The raiding broadcaster is blocked from the targeted channel.
- The targeted channel doesn't accept raids from this broadcaster.
- There are too many viewers in the raiding party.
- The IDs in from_broadcaster_id and to_broadcaster_id cannot be the same ID.
- The ID in the from_broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
- The ID in the to_broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in from_broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the request’s OAuth token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:raids scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404: - The targeted channel was not found.
codes.409: - The broadcaster is already in the process of raiding another channel.
codes.429: - The broadcaster exceeded the number of raid requests that they may make. The limit is 10 requests within a 10-minute window.

Start a raid.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:raids* scope.

Cancel a raid.long:
Cancel a pending raid.
You can cancel a raid at any point up until the broadcaster clicks *Raid Now* in the Twitch UX or the 90-second countdown expires.
*Rate Limit*: The limit is 10 requests within a 10-minute window.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that initiated the raid. This ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

codes.204: The pending raid was successfully canceled.
codes.400: - The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID found in the request’s OAuth token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:raids scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.404: - The broadcaster doesn't have a pending raid to cancel.
codes.429: - The broadcaster exceeded the number of raid requests that they may make. The limit is 10 requests within a 10-minute window.

Cancel a raid.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:raids* scope.

Get Channel Stream Schedule.long: Gets the broadcaster’s streaming schedule. You can get the entire schedule or specific segments of the schedule. [Learn More](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/channel-page-setup#Schedule)

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the streaming schedule you want to get.

params.name: id
params.description: The ID of the scheduled segment to return. To specify more than one segment, include the ID of each segment you want to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs.

params.name: start_time
params.description: The UTC date and time that identifies when in the broadcaster’s schedule to start returning segments. If not specified, the request returns segments starting after the current UTC date and time. Specify the date and time in RFC3339 format (for example, `2022-09-01T00:00:00Z`).

params.name: utc_offset
params.description: Not supported.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 25 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s streaming schedule.

reqBody.name: segments
reqBody.description: The list of broadcasts in the broadcaster’s streaming schedule.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this broadcast segment.

reqBody.name: start_time
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast starts.

reqBody.name: end_time
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast ends.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The broadcast segment’s title.

reqBody.name: canceled_until
reqBody.description: Indicates whether the broadcaster canceled this segment of a recurring broadcast. If the broadcaster canceled this segment, this field is set to the same value that’s in the `end_time` field; otherwise, it’s set to *null*.

reqBody.name: category
reqBody.description: The type of content that the broadcaster plans to stream or *null* if not specified.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the category that best represents the content that the broadcaster plans to stream. For example, the game’s ID if the broadcaster will play a game or the Just Chatting ID if the broadcaster will host a talk show.

reqBody.name: name
reqBody.description: The name of the category. For example, the game’s title if the broadcaster will playing a game or Just Chatting if the broadcaster will host a talk show.

reqBody.name: is_recurring
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether the broadcast is part of a recurring series that streams at the same time each week or is a one-time broadcast. Is *true* if the broadcast is part of a recurring series.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the broadcast schedule.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_name
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s display name.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_login
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s login name.

reqBody.name: vacation
reqBody.description: The dates when the broadcaster is on vacation and not streaming. Is set to *null* if vacation mode is not enabled.

reqBody.name: start_time
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcaster’s vacation starts.

reqBody.name: end_time
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcaster’s vacation ends.

reqBody.name: pagination
reqBody.description: The information used to page through a list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read more](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination).

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Set the request’s after query parameter to this value.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the broadcaster’s streaming schedule.
codes.400:

codes.401:

codes.403: - Only partners and affiliates may add non-recurring broadcast segments.

Update Channel Stream Schedule.short: Updates the broadcaster’s schedule settings, such as scheduling a vacation.
Update Channel Stream Schedule.long: Updates the broadcaster’s schedule settings, such as scheduling a vacation.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose schedule settings you want to update. The ID must match the user ID in the user access token.

params.name: is_vacation_enabled
params.description: A Boolean value that indicates whether the broadcaster has scheduled a vacation. Set to *true* to enable Vacation Mode and add vacation dates, or *false* to cancel a previously scheduled vacation.

params.name: vacation_start_time
params.description: The UTC date and time of when the broadcaster’s vacation starts. Specify the date and time in RFC3339 format (for example, 2021-05-16T00:00:00Z). Required if is_vacation_enabled is *true*.

params.name: vacation_end_time
params.description: The UTC date and time of when the broadcaster’s vacation ends. Specify the date and time in RFC3339 format (for example, 2021-05-30T23:59:59Z). Required if is_vacation_enabled is *true*.

params.name: timezone
params.description: The time zone that the broadcaster broadcasts from. Specify the time zone using [IANA time zone database](https://www.iana.org/time-zones) format (for example, America/New_York). Required if is_vacation_enabled is *true*.

codes.204: Successfully updated the broadcaster’s schedule settings.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id query parameter is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter is not valid.
- The format of the string in vacation_start_time is not valid.
- The format of the string in vacation_end_time is not valid.
- The date in vacation_end_time must be later than the date in vacation_start_time.
codes.401:
- The ID in the broadcaster_id query parameter must match the user ID in the user access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:manage:schedule scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the Client-Id header must match the client ID in the access token.
codes.404: - The broadcaster's schedule was not found.

For recurring segments, updating a segment’s title, category, duration, and timezone, changes all segments in the recurring schedule, not just the specified segment.

Search Categories.short: Gets the games or categories that match the specified query.
Search Categories.long:
Gets the games or categories that match the specified query.
To match, the category’s name must contain all parts of the query string. For example, if the query string is 42, the response includes any category name that contains 42 in the title. If the query string is a phrase like love computer, the response includes any category name that contains the words love and computer anywhere in the name. The comparison is case insensitive.

params.name: query
params.description: The URI-encoded search string. For example, encode #archery as `%23archery` and search strings like angel of death as `angel%20of%20death`.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of games or categories that match the query. The list is empty if there are no matches.

reqBody.name: box_art_url
reqBody.description: A URL to an image of the game’s box art or streaming category.

reqBody.name: name
reqBody.description: The name of the game or category.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that uniquely identifies the game or category.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of category names that matched the specified query string.
codes.400: - The query query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Search Channels.short: Gets the channels that match the specified query and have streamed content within the past 6 months.
Search Channels.long:
Gets the channels that match the specified query and have streamed content within the past 6 months.
The fields that the API uses for comparison depends on the value that the live_only query parameter is set to. If live_only is *false*, the API matches on the broadcaster’s login name. However, if live_only is *true*, the API matches on the broadcaster’s name and category name.
To match, the beginning of the broadcaster’s name or category must match the query string. The comparison is case insensitive. If the query string is angel_of_death, it matches all names that begin with angel_of_death. However, if the query string is a phrase like angel of death, it matches to names starting with angelofdeath or names starting with angel_of_death.
By default, the results include both live and offline channels. To get only live channels set the live_only query parameter to *true*.

params.name: query
params.description: The URI-encoded search string. For example, encode search strings like angel of death as `angel%20of%20death`.

params.name: live_only
params.description: A Boolean value that determines whether the response includes only channels that are currently streaming live. Set to *true* to get only channels that are streaming live; otherwise, *false* to get live and offline channels. The default is *false*.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of channels that match the query. The list is empty if there are no matches.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_language
reqBody.description: The ISO 639-1 two-letter language code of the language used by the broadcaster. For example, en for English. If the broadcaster uses a language not in the list of [supported stream languages](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/languages-on-twitch#streamlang), the value is other.

reqBody.name: broadcaster_login
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s login name.

reqBody.name: display_name
reqBody.description: The broadcaster’s display name.

reqBody.name: game_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played.

reqBody.name: game_name
reqBody.description: The name of the game that the broadcaster is playing or last played.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that uniquely identifies the channel (this is the broadcaster’s ID).

reqBody.name: is_live
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether the broadcaster is streaming live. Is *true* if the broadcaster is streaming live; otherwise, *false*.

reqBody.name: tag_ids
reqBody.description: *IMPORTANT* As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the `tags` field.The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see [List of All Tags](https://www.twitch.tv/directory/all/tags). The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

reqBody.name: tags
reqBody.description: The tags applied to the channel.

reqBody.name: thumbnail_url
reqBody.description: A URL to a thumbnail of the broadcaster’s profile image.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if the broadcaster didn’t set it.

reqBody.name: started_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcaster started streaming. The string is empty if the broadcaster is not streaming live.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of category names that matched the specified query string.
codes.400: - The query query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster that owns the channel. The ID must match the user ID in the access token.

reqBody.description: A list that contains the channel’s stream key.

reqBody.name: stream_key
reqBody.description: The channel’s stream key.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the stream’s key.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id field is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id field is not valid.
codes.401:
- The ID in broadcaster_id must match the user ID in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the channel:read:stream_key scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header must match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: The user must complete additional steps in order to stream. Present the user with the returned error message.

Get Stream Key.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:read:stream_key* scope.

Get Streams.short: Gets a list of all streams.
Get Streams.long: Gets a list of all streams. The list is in descending order by the number of viewers watching the stream. Because viewers come and go during a stream, it’s possible to find duplicate or missing streams in the list as you page through the results.

params.name: user_id
params.description: A user ID used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams of those users that are broadcasting. You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. To specify multiple IDs, include the user_id parameter for each user. For example, `&user_id=1234&user_id=5678`.

params.name: user_login
params.description: A user login name used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams of those users that are broadcasting. You may specify a maximum of 100 login names. To specify multiple names, include the user_login parameter for each user. For example, `&user_login=foo&user_login=bar`.

params.name: game_id
params.description: A game (category) ID used to filter the list of streams. Returns only the streams that are broadcasting the game (category). You may specify a maximum of 100 IDs. To specify multiple IDs, include the game_id parameter for each game. For example, `&game_id=9876&game_id=5432`.

params.name: type
params.description:
The type of stream to filter the list of streams by. Possible values are:- all
- live
The default is all.

params.name: language
params.description: A language code used to filter the list of streams. Returns only streams that broadcast in the specified language. Specify the language using an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the broadcast uses a language not in the list of [supported stream languages](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/languages-on-twitch#streamlang).You may specify a maximum of 100 language codes. To specify multiple languages, include the language parameter for each language. For example, `&language=de&language=fr`.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100 items per page. The default is 20.

params.name: before
params.description: The cursor used to get the previous page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of streams.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the stream. You can use this ID later to look up the video on demand (VOD).

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the user that’s broadcasting the stream.

reqBody.name: user_login
reqBody.description: The user’s login name.

reqBody.name: user_name
reqBody.description: The user’s display name.

reqBody.name: game_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the category or game being played.

reqBody.name: game_name
reqBody.description: The name of the category or game being played.

reqBody.name: type
reqBody.description:
The type of stream. Possible values are:- live
If an error occurs, this field is set to an empty string.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if not set.

reqBody.name: tags
reqBody.description: The tags applied to the stream.

reqBody.name: viewer_count
reqBody.description: The number of users watching the stream.

reqBody.name: started_at

reqBody.name: language

reqBody.name: thumbnail_url

For a list of possible tags, see [List of All Tags](https://www.twitch.tv/directory/all/tags). The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

reqBody.name: is_mature

reqBody.name: pagination

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Set the request’s after or before query parameter to this value depending on whether you’re paging forwards or backwards.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of streams.

Get Followed Streams.short: Gets the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.
Get Followed Streams.long: Gets the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.

params.name: user_id

reqBody.name: data

Because viewers come and go during a stream, it’s possible to find duplicate or missing streams in the list as you page through the results. The list is empty if none of the followed broadcasters are streaming live.

reqBody.name: type
reqBody.description:
The type of stream. Possible values are:- live
If an error occurs, this field is set to an empty string.

reqBody.name: title
reqBody.description: The stream’s title. Is an empty string if not set.

reqBody.name: viewer_count
reqBody.description: The number of users watching the stream.

reqBody.name: started_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the broadcast began.

reqBody.name: language
reqBody.description: The language that the stream uses. This is an ISO 639-1 two-letter language code or other if the stream uses a language not in the list of [supported stream languages](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/languages-on-twitch#streamlang).

reqBody.name: thumbnail_url

reqBody.description: *IMPORTANT* As of February 28, 2023, this field is deprecated and returns only an empty array. If you use this field, please update your code to use the `tags` field.The list of tags that apply to the stream. The list contains IDs only when the channel is steaming live. For a list of possible tags, see [List of All Tags](https://www.twitch.tv/directory/all/tags). The list doesn’t include Category Tags.

reqBody.name: is_mature

reqBody.name: pagination

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of broadcasters that the user follows and that are streaming live.
codes.400: - The user_id query parameter is required.
codes.401:
- The ID in user_id must match the user ID found in the access token.
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the user:read:follows scope.
- The OAuth token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Get Followed Streams.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *user:read:follows* scope.

Create Stream Marker.short: Adds a marker to a live stream.
Create Stream Marker.long:
Adds a marker to a live stream. A marker is an arbitrary point in a live stream that the broadcaster or editor wants to mark, so they can return to that spot later to create video highlights (see Video Producer, Highlights in the Twitch UX).
You may not add markers:
- If the stream is not live
- If the stream has not enabled video on demand (VOD)
- If the stream is a premiere (a live, first-viewing event that combines uploaded videos with live chat)
- If the stream is a rerun of a past broadcast, including past premieres.

reqBody.name: user_id
reqBody.description: The ID of the broadcaster that’s streaming content. This ID must match the user ID in the access token or the user in the access token must be one of the broadcaster’s editors.

reqBody.name: description
reqBody.description: A short description of the marker to help the user remember why they marked the location. The maximum length of the description is 140 characters.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: A list that contains the single marker that you added.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this marker.

reqBody.name: created_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the user created the marker.

reqBody.name: position_seconds
reqBody.description: The relative offset (in seconds) of the marker from the beginning of the stream.

reqBody.name: description
reqBody.description: A description that the user gave the marker to help them remember why they marked the location.

codes.200: Successfully created the marker.
codes.400:
- The `user_id` field is required.
- The length of the string in the `description` field is too long.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain a user access token.
- The user access token must include the user:manage:broadcast scope.
- The access token is not valid.
- The client ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.
codes.403: - The user in the access token is not authorized to create video markers for the user in the `user_id` field. The user in the access token must own the video or they must be one of the broadcaster's editors.
codes.404:
- The user in the `user_id` field is not streaming live.
- The ID in the user_id field is not valid.
- The user hasn't enabled video on demand (VOD).

Create Stream Marker.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:manage:broadcast* scope.

Get Stream Markers.short: Gets a list of markers from the user’s most recent stream or from the specified VOD/video.
Get Stream Markers.long: Gets a list of markers from the user’s most recent stream or from the specified VOD/video. A marker is an arbitrary point in a live stream that the broadcaster or editor marked, so they can return to that spot later to create video highlights (see Video Producer, Highlights in the Twitch UX).
Get Stream Markers.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *user:read:broadcast* or *channel:manage:broadcast* scope.

Get Broadcaster Subscriptions.short: Gets a list of users that subscribe to the specified broadcaster.
Get Broadcaster Subscriptions.long: Gets a list of users that subscribe to the specified broadcaster.
Get Broadcaster Subscriptions.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *channel:read:subscriptions* scope.

Check User Subscription.short: Checks whether the user subscribes to the broadcaster’s channel.
Check User Subscription.long: Checks whether the user subscribes to the broadcaster’s channel.
Check User Subscription.auth: Requires a [user access token](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/authentication#user-access-tokens) that includes the *user:read:subscriptions* scope.

Get All Stream Tags.short: Gets the list of all stream tags that Twitch defines. You can also filter the list by one or more tag IDs.
Get All Stream Tags.long:
*IMPORTANT* Twitch is moving from Twitch-defined tags to channel-defined tags. *IMPORTANT* As of February 28, 2023, this endpoint returns an empty array. On July 13, 2023, it will return a 410 response.
Gets a list of all stream tags that Twitch defines. The broadcaster may apply any of these to their channel except automatic tags. For an online list of the possible tags, see [List of All Tags](https://www.twitch.tv/directory/all/tags).

params.name: tag_id
params.description: The ID of the tag to get. Used to filter the list of tags. To specify more than one tag, include the tag_id parameter for each tag to get. For example, `tag_id=1234&tag_id=5678`. The maximum number of IDs you may specify is 100. Ignores invalid IDs but not duplicate IDs.

params.name: first
params.description: The maximum number of items to return per page in the response. The minimum page size is 1 item per page and the maximum is 100. The default is 20.

params.name: after
params.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. The *Pagination* object in the response contains the cursor’s value. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of stream tags that the broadcaster can apply to their channel.

reqBody.name: tag_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this tag.

reqBody.name: is_auto
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether the tag is an automatic tag. An automatic tag is one that Twitch adds to the stream. Broadcasters may not add automatic tags to their channel. The value is *true* if the tag is an automatic tag; otherwise, *false*.

reqBody.name: localization_names
reqBody.description: A dictionary that contains the localized names of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized name.

reqBody.name: localization_descriptions
reqBody.description: A dictionary that contains the localized descriptions of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<country/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized description.

reqBody.name: pagination
reqBody.description: The information used to page through the list of results. The object is empty if there are no more pages left to page through. [Read More](https://dev.twitch.tv/docs/api/guide#pagination)

reqBody.name: cursor
reqBody.description: The cursor used to get the next page of results. Set the request’s after query parameter to this value to page forwards through the results.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of tags.
codes.400:
- The tag_id query parameter is empty (for example, `&tag_id=`).
- The list of tag IDs is too long.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the access token.

Get Stream Tags.short: Gets the list of stream tags that the broadcaster or Twitch added to their channel.
Get Stream Tags.long:
*IMPORTANT* Twitch is moving from Twitch-defined tags to channel-defined tags. *IMPORTANT* As of February 28, 2023, this endpoint returns an empty array. On July 13, 2023, it will return a 410 response. If you use this endpoint, please update your code to use [Get Channel Information](#get-channel-information).
Gets the list of stream tags that the broadcaster or Twitch added to their channel.

params.name: broadcaster_id
params.description: The ID of the broadcaster whose stream tags you want to get.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of stream tags. The list is empty if the broadcaster or Twitch hasn’t added tags to the broadcaster’s channel.

reqBody.name: tag_id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies this tag.

reqBody.name: is_auto
reqBody.description: A Boolean value that determines whether the tag is an automatic tag. An automatic tag is one that Twitch adds to the stream. Broadcasters may not add automatic tags to their channel. The value is *true* if the tag is an automatic tag; otherwise, *false*.

reqBody.name: localization_names
reqBody.description: A dictionary that contains the localized names of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<coutry/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized name.

reqBody.name: localization_descriptions
reqBody.description: A dictionary that contains the localized descriptions of the tag. The key is in the form, <locale>-<coutry/region>. For example, en-us. The value is the localized description.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the list of tags.
codes.400:
- The broadcaster_id field is required.
- The ID in the broadcaster_id field is not valid.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must specify an app access token or user access token.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID in the Client-Id header must match the Client ID in the access token.

Get Teams.long: Gets information about the specified Twitch team. [Read More](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/twitch-teams)

reqBody.description: The UTC date and time (in RFC3339 format) of when the team was created.

reqBody.name: updated_at

reqBody.description: A URL to a thumbnail image of the team’s logo.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the team's information.
codes.400:

Get Users.short: Gets information about one or more users.
Get Users.long: Gets information about one or more users. You may look up users using their user ID, login name, or both but the sum total of the number of users you may look up is 100. For example, you may specify 50 IDs and 50 names or 100 IDs or names, but you cannot specify 100 IDs and 100 names. If you don’t specify IDs or login names, the request returns information about the user in the access token if you specify a user access token. To include the user’s verified email address in the response, you must use a user access token that includes the *user:read:email* scope.

params.name: id
params.description: The ID of the user to get. To specify more than one user, include the id parameter for each user to get. For example, `id=1234&id=5678`. The maximum number of IDs you may specify is 100.

params.name: login
params.description: The login name of the user to get. To specify more than one user, include the login parameter for each user to get. For example, `login=foo&login=bar`. The maximum number of login names you may specify is 100.

reqBody.name: data
reqBody.description: The list of users.

reqBody.name: id
reqBody.description: An ID that identifies the user.

reqBody.name: login
reqBody.description: The user’s login name.

reqBody.name: display_name
reqBody.description: The user’s display name.

reqBody.name: type
reqBody.description:
The type of user. Possible values are: - admin — Twitch administrator
- global_mod
- staff — Twitch staff
- "" — Normal user

reqBody.name: broadcaster_type
reqBody.description:
The type of broadcaster. Possible values are: - affiliate — An affiliate broadcaster [affiliate broadcaster](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/joining-the-affiliate-program target=)
- partner — A partner broadcaster [partner broadcaster](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/partner-program-overview)
- "" — A normal broadcaster

reqBody.name: description
reqBody.description: The user’s description of their channel.

reqBody.name: profile_image_url
reqBody.description: A URL to the user’s profile image.

reqBody.name: offline_image_url
reqBody.description: A URL to the user’s offline image.

reqBody.name: view_count
reqBody.description: The number of times the user’s channel has been viewed. *NOTE*: This field has been deprecated (see [Get Users API endpoint – “view_count” deprecation](https://discuss.dev.twitch.tv/t/get-users-api-endpoint-view-count-deprecation/37777)). Any data in this field is not valid and should not be used.

reqBody.name: email
reqBody.description: The user’s verified email address. The object includes this field only if the user access token includes the *user:read:email* scope. If the request contains more than one user, only the user associated with the access token that provided consent will include an email address — the email address for all other users will be empty.

reqBody.name: created_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time that the user’s account was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

codes.200: Successfully retrieved the specified users’ information.
codes.400:
- The *id* or *login* query parameter is required unless the request uses a user access token.
- The request exceeded the maximum allowed number of *id* and/or *login* query parameters.
codes.401:
- The Authorization header is required and must contain an app access token or user access token.
- The access token is not valid.
- The ID specified in the Client-Id header does not match the client ID specified in the access token.

Update User.long:
Updates the specified user’s information. The user ID in the OAuth token identifies the user whose information you want to update.
To include the user’s verified email address in the response, the user access token must also include the *user:read:email* scope.

reqBody.description: The user's display name.

The type of user. Possible values are:- admin — Twitch administrator

- partner — A [partner broadcaster](https://help.twitch.tv/s/article/partner-program-overview)
- "" — A normal broadcaster

reqBody.description: A URL to the user's offline image.

reqBody.description: The number of times the user's channel has been viewed.*NOTE*: This field has been deprecated (see [Get Users API endpoint – "view_count" deprecation](https://discuss.dev.twitch.tv/t/get-users-api-endpoint-view-count-deprecation/37777)). Any data in this field is not valid and should not be used.

reqBody.name: email

The object includes this field only if the user access token includes the *user:read:email* scope.If the request contains more than one user, only the user associated with the access token that provided consent will include an email address — the email address for all other users will be empty.

reqBody.name: created_at
reqBody.description: The UTC date and time that the user's account was created. The timestamp is in RFC3339 format.

codes.200: Successfully updated the specified user's information.

codes.401:
